question: A simple pendulum has a period of 2 seconds on Earth. If the pendulum is taken to the Moon, where the acceleration due to gravity is about 1/6 that of Earth, what will be the new period of the pendulum?
solution: The period of a simple pendulum is given by the formula T = 2π√(L/g), where L is the length of the pendulum and g is the acceleration due to gravity. The period is proportional to the square root of g, so if g decreases by a factor of 6, the period will increase by a factor of √6. Thus, the new period on the Moon will be T_moon = T_earth × √6 = 2 s × √6 ≈ 4.90 s.
